714085f-b.text:
421 East 6lst Street, north side, between York and First Aves., showing the Col. Smith House (also known as the Adams Mansion). This house was built in 1799 by Colonel Smith, a son-in-law of President Adams. One version states that it was built in 1777 by Peter Pra Van Sairt for a stable to his resiience and he sold (1765) the mansion, stables and other buildings to Col. Wm. S. Smith. The latter failed in business and his stable became a tavern and was used as such until 1830 when Jeremiah Fowle purchased it, whose daughter occupied it until 1906. The Consolidated Gas Company sold this building in December 1924 to the Colonial Dames. This set consists of 4 views
taken at the same time.
February 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

714080f-b.text:
421 East 6lst Street, north side, between York and First Aves. This house was built in 1790 as a wedding gift to one of John Adams' daughters. At the time of this picture it is occupied by the Museum of the City of New York. In 1931, however, the Museum will move uptown to its new building on the east side of Fifth Avenue from 103rd to 104th Streets, and this house will
be oocupied by the Colonial Dames of America.
September 15, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, more of a side view.
September 15, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

421 East 6lst Street, north side, between York (Ave. A.) and First Aves. Old stone building shown, is the Col. Smith Mansion, and was built in 1799. Note the gas holders of the Consolidated Gas Co.
September 23, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same; showing a closer view.
September 23, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Another perspective of the same view. Note a portion of Cornell Medical College and New York Hospital Centre, in the distant background.
September 23, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

709085f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., east side, north from East 6lst to 62nd Streets, showing some of the prigate houses that are fast disappearing from this famous thoroughfare. 'Some of the residents are: Geraldine R. Dodge, No. 1 East 61st Street (also 800 Fifth Ave.); Chas. B. Halsey, 803 Fifth Ave., (white building); W.E. Roosevelt, No. 804 Fifth Ave., and the Knickerbocker Club, No. 2 East 62nd Street (also No. 805-9 Fifth Ave.). View No. 2 of this set is in a southeastward direction from a point in Central Park on a line with 62nd Street which appears on the left.
1December 19, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
Ng. ~2.50 2
